column1: Robert Durst indicted in New York in death of his first wife, Kathie
column3: Robert Durst, 78, will stand trial in New York for the killing of Kathie McCormack, who was last seen in January 1982.

column1: Irvine man faces federal charges in violent attack on American Airlines flight attendant
column3: The Oct. 27 New York-to-Santa Ana was forced to make an emergency landing in Denver after authorities say the passenger punched a crew member in the face.

column1: Climate change is now the main driver of increasing wildfire weather, study finds
column3: New study says climate change is essentially two-thirds to 88% responsible for the conditions driving wildfire woes in the Western United States.

column1: L.A. city attorney backs ballot plan to double the size of the City Council in 2022
column3: In the wake of L.A.'s debate over redistricting, City Atty. Mike Feuer said he wants to move faster on a plan to expand the City Council to 30 members.

column1: For 70 years, Christmas trees were the family business. Then came drought. And fire
column3: For three generations, farming trees has brought joy and heartbreak. Now their livelihood is at stake.

column1: Unvaccinated teens in L.A. are more likely to test positive for coronavirus than adults
column3: The trend illustrates how a group less likely to have been vaccinated in the nation's most populous county is playing an outsize role in continuing transmission of the highly contagious Delta variant.

column1: Obamacare open enrollment begins. Find out if you qualify for higher subsidies
column3: Additional federal subsidies make Covered California healthcare plans more affordable for more Californians in 2022.

column1: Op-Ed: By all means, make redistricting in Los Angeles truly independent
column3: The redistricting commission's map isn't perfect, but we worked to make the process fair, transparent and inclusive. Can the City Council say the same?

column1: Halloween party in Long Beach ends with six injured by hit-and-run driver, police say
column3: Ambulances responded and rushed five adults and one youth to local hospitals.

column1: American Airlines cancels 28 flights out of LAX and 1,800 nationwide
column3: The airline has canceled 1,800 flights nationwide since Friday, citing staffing shortages and bad weather.

column3: Anger grows at two private schools in Carpinteria and Boulder as investigations into allegations of sexual misconduct by a teacher toward students continue.

column1: Fortuneteller bilked $50,000 from woman to get rid of parasites and a curse, police say

column1: Sheriff warns vaccine mandate causing 'mass exodus' among personnel

column3: Inside LAPD Chief Michel Moore's weekly crime briefing, commanders talked of the 'compounding' violence.

column1: USC's 'Greek experience' under fire even as fraternities gain in popularity post-pandemic
column3: The USC furor signals a pivotal moment for the American college fraternity system, as more Greek members and student coalitions mount protests against an often toxic culture.

column1: Hassina Leelarathna, co-founder of the only Sri Lankan newspaper in the U.S., dies at 73
column3: She was a presence at rallies and protests, both interviewing people for the newspaper and at times, taking the megaphone to pump up the crowds.

column1: Column: This priest died of COVID-19. His congregants got vaccinated in his honor
column3: Francisco Valdovinos was a beloved priest in the Coachella Valley. His death from COVID-19 spurred vaccinations.

column1: 'The most terrible death of all is to be forgotten': The artist who made Day of the Dead matter
column3: Folk artist Ofelia Esparza, L.A.'s most admired altar maker, reminds a somber city of the meaning of Día de los Muertos. Hint: It's not Mexican Halloween.

column1: Homeless veterans prepare for move onto VA grounds in West Los Angeles
column3: The encampment, adjacent to the historic Veterans Affairs campus in West Los Angeles, has become a focal point for homelessness in the city, with mayoral candidates making visits regularly over the last year.

column1: Three men killed in separate shootings in Los Angeles

column3: Karly Katona will oversee the 10th District following the City Council's decision to strip indicted Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas of his duties.

column1: Shooting at home of Gilroy council member leaves 1 dead, 3 injured; suspect arrested
column3: The shooting took place during a party on Saturday at the home of Gilroy City Council Member Rebeca Armendariz.

column3: L.A. County sheriff's deputies cleared an encampment outside the Veterans Administration complex near Brentwood after the VA promised to find housing for the veterans living there.

column1: Water main break sends cascade down Cahuenga Boulevard near Universal Studios
column3: Authorities haven't provided a repair timeline for the nearly 90-year-old pipe.

column3: L.A. County lawyers had requested the exam, arguing the basketball star's widow wasn't traumatized by news that sheriff's deputies shared grim images of the crash scene.

column1: Architect slams UC Santa Barbara mega-dorm as 'social, psychological experiment,' quits in protest
column3: The $1.5-billion project would house more than 4,500 students, but 94% of the rooms would have no windows.

column1: Riverside man who abused puppy in social media videos gets 2 years in prison

column1: A top LAFD official accessed confidential complaint files while he was under investigation

column1: Grieving relatives sue facilities over COVID-19 deaths. Nursing homes say they're immune

column1: 'Rust' tragedy highlights labor tensions in New Mexico as production surges

column1: West Hollywood boosts minimum wage for some workers to $17.64 an hour

column1: Pomona defunded school police. But after a shooting, campus officers are coming back
column3: In an emergency decision, the school board reverses a four-month old decision and is returning uniformed police officers to high school campuses.

column1: Hope after wildfire: Tiny sequoias could grow into giants

column3: Skateboarding in the U.S. has been dominated by white dudes. Lately women, people of color and LGBTQ people are creating room for themselves.

column3: With BIG: LEAP, some 3,200 low-income Angelenos will get $1,000 every month for one year. Georgia Horton, a recipient of the Compton Pledge, is worried about what comes next for those who will come to depend on that money.

column3: About 15,000 runners were expected to participate in the L.A. Marathon, which had a 26.2-mile route from downtown to the finish line in Century City.

column1: A groundbreaking Chicano series, stored 50 years in a garage, reemerges
column3: Shockingly relevant 50 years after it aired in 1971, a Chicano TV series is digitized after its host rescued it from a box in his Orange County garage.

column1: An LAPD-caused explosion cost them their home. After months of limbo, they went to the desert

column1: Column: L.A. County's sheriff called me a 'vendido,' a sellout. Let's talk about selling out
column3: Among Latinos, to call someone a vendido stings even more than the English translation. It's a person who not only forgets their roots but works actively to quash their former comrades.

column3: The UC Hastings College of the Law will soon no longer bear the name of its founder, who profited off the mass killings of Indigenous people.

column1: Grandma and Disneyland: Parents who jumped at COVID shots for kids crave 'normal life'

column1: Vexed by dust pollution, officials around Mono Lake call on Los Angeles to cease water diversions
column3: Mono County wants the City of Los Angeles to cease water diversions around Mono Lake, saying low lake levels are causing harmful dust pollution.

column1: Judge dismisses L.A. deputy's retaliation lawsuit

column1: Podcast: How Filipino Americans are the Latinos of Asia
column3: Anthony Ocampo's book makes a bold analysis: Filipino Americans are the Latinos of Asia. He explains why.

column1: Prescribed burns are key to reducing wildfire risk, but federal agencies are lagging

column1: This UC firearms researcher says America is on a collision course with disaster. We need to listen
column3: A study by UC Davis' Garen Wintemute of the California Firearms Violence Research Center notes that The unprecedented surge in firearms purchasing … shows no sign of abating and risks becoming part of a new normal for the USA.

column1: LAUSD to spend $5 million on gift cards, prizes to encourage students to get vaccinated
column3: Students 12 and older are supposed to have their first shot by Nov. 21.

column1: L.A. County to investigate alleged abuse of 4-year-old by his foster mother
column3: The investigation will focus on the handling of the case by the Department of Children and Family Services and other agencies, including how social workers addressed language barriers.

column1: O.C. supervisors set to approve majority Latino district amid allegations of gerrymandering
column3: It has been 15 years since there was a Latino representative on the five-member board.

column1: UC lecturer strike averted as union hails tentative agreement as its 'best contract' ever
column3: A massive strike by more than 6,000 UC lecturers was averted after the union and university reached what UC-AFT called its 'best contract' in history.

column1: City controller calls for fixes to L.A.'s sidewalk repair program
column3: City Controller Ron Galperin called on L.A. agencies to change the way they repair city sidewalks, by targeting smaller segments of broken pavement.

column1: House to censure GOP's Gosar over cartoon showing him stab AOC
column3: Rep. Paul Gosar is set to become the first member to be censured by the House in more than 10 years.

column1: 3.8 quake hits in San Ramon, Calif.
column3: The earthquake occurred less than a mile from Danville, three miles from Castro Valley, four miles from Alamo and four miles from Dublin, Calif.

column1: Caltech grad charged with setting Fawn fire is declared mentally unfit to stand trial
column3: Alexandra Souverneva, a Caltech graduate accused of setting the Fawn fire in Shasta County on Sept. 22, is found mentally unfit to stand trial.

column1: House censures GOP's Gosar over cartoon showing him stab AOC
column3: Rep. Paul Gosar becomes the first member to be censured by the House in more than 10 years.

column1: A huge California budget surplus will test legal spending limit, analysts warn
column3: California's constitutional cap on state spending is likely to dictate how lawmakers divvy up almost all of a $31-billion tax surplus, analysts say.

column1: 2028 L.A. Olympics: Agreement outlines key issues but final price tag remains unclear
column3: A tentative agreement between L.A. leaders and organizers of the 2028 Olympics details the issues facing the city as it prepares to host the Games.

column1: Angelenos grouse, others rejoice at Staples Center's new name
column3: 'This just sounds awful,' says one local, wearing a Lakers hat outside of what will soon be called the Crypto.com Arena.

column1: At a Northern California clinic, 14 children get double the correct dose of the COVID-19 vaccine
column3: Medical professionals have assured parents that the short-term effects should wear off in a few days and that the long-term risks are likely to be minimal.

column1: Woman who says CHP officer sexually assaulted her, followed her home to get $4.5 million
column3: A second female motorist claims she too was sexually battered by the same now-former officer that day in 2018.

column1: 77 L.A. city employees lose pay after refusing to sign notice for vaccine mandate
column3: Dozens of Los Angeles city employees are now going unpaid after refusing to sign notices that directed them to get COVID-19 vaccines by a December deadline, Mayor Eric Garcetti said Wednesday.

column1: LAUSD to end weekly COVID tests and spend $5 million on prizes to encourage vaccinations
column3: Students 12 and older are supposed to have their first shot by Nov. 21.

column1: Critical role of UC lecturers affirmed as strike is averted, tentative agreement reached
column3: At 4 a.m. Wednesday, the union representing lecturers had its demands met regarding paid family leave, rehiring rights and workload requirements.

column1: 'Blasphemy': Some Angelenos grouse, others rejoice at Staples Center's new name
column3: This just sounds awful, says one local, wearing a Lakers hat outside of what will soon be called the Crypto.com Arena.

column1: Woman killed, man injured in Westmont shooting, authorities say
column3: A woman was killed and a man seriously injured in a shooting Wednesday in the South Los Angeles neighborhood of Westmont, the L.A. County Sheriff's Department said.

column1: UC slams the door on standardized admissions tests, nixing any SAT alternative
column3: The University of California has slammed the door shut on standardized testing for admissions, saying no alternative to the SAT can avoid bias based on race, income.

column1: California community college students choosing jobs over class likely fuel enrollment drop
column3: California's overall 6.5% drop in undergraduate enrollment is higher than the national average and the sixth highest in the nation.

column1: Trial of L.A. County sheriff's deputy charged with manslaughter now in hands of jurors
column3: Deputy Luke Liu could face up to 11 years in prison if convicted in the 2016 shooting death of unarmed Francisco Garcia at a Norwalk gas station.

column1: California's coronavirus cases top 5 million as hospitalizations continue to drop
column3: The sobering total underscores the pervasiveness of the COVID-19 pandemic during its nearly two-year rampage through the state.

column1: Philippines church leader charged with coercing sex under threat of 'eternal damnation'
column3: Federal authorities charge the leader of a Philippines-based church with sex trafficking and forcing followers to beg for money in the U.S. to fund his lavish lifestyle.

column1: L.A. schools will relax some student mask rules, ease COVID-19 testing. What to know
column3: For the upcoming semester, LAUSD students 12 and up will need to be vaccinated. Weekly COVID testing will end, and masks won't be required outdoors.

column1: Column: Republican Kevin Faulconer flopped as a candidate for California governor. So why not try again?
column3: Faulconer says another run against Gavin Newsom for California governor would be different if issues were the focus in a one-on-one race.

column1: A USC building stripped of eugenicist's name will instead honor a Native American alumnus
column3: The name of Rufus B. von KleinSmid was stripped and the building now honors Joseph Medicine Crow, who was awarded the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor.

column1: Suspected Shadow Hills prowler captured after days-long manhunt
column3: Police say Benjamin Renteria, 25, is responsible for nine burglaries in the last two months.

column1: California's MyTurn site allows all adults to get COVID booster appointments
column3: The FDA and CDC are expected to officially make booster shots available to all fully vaccinated adults by the end of this week.

column1: L.A.'s COVID rules: Mask and vaccine guidance for out-of-town visitors
column3: Some places in Los Angeles city and county won't let you in without proof of full COVID vaccination. Others will just ask you to wear a mask.

column1: Column: Don't blame politicians for California's sky-high gas prices. Blame COVID-19
column3: UC Berkeley energy economist Severin Borenstein says California oil production is virtually irrelevant to the global price of crude.

column1: Podcast: Social media's Latino misinformation problem
column3: Meta, Google and other online giants know that disinformation plagues Latinos — so what will they do about it?

column1: Sixty-foot waves exploded off the Pacific Coast during October's bomb cyclone
column3: October's bomb cyclone generated massive waves along with heavy rain and high winds.

column1: From Alabama to California, a trip along the broken supply chain
column3: The great American supply chain has hit the skids, and a Times reporter  took a cross-country trip to check out the economic mayhem.

column1: String of LAPD shootings exposes L.A.'s broken mental health system, officials say
column3: In L.A., mentally ill people are cycled through what police, mental health officials and advocates agree is a revolving door of temporary psychiatric units and jail wards, never getting the long-term care they need.
